title: RANKED - Corrections to placement results and ranks
body:
Update from the team working on the fix: http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/7i1WBYXy-update-on-preseason-ranked

Hi everyone,

If you've been playing Ranked or reading the Boards you may have noticed some wild changes in placement rankings after this morning. This is the result of a fix that went out this morning to correct all the previously wild placement results and matchmaking that was going on until now.

We've made changes to OCE first, because it was the first region to release Ranked Flex. These changes were aimed at correcting MMR problems that originated from issues with Ranked Flex's launch. These problems with everyone's MMR have caused most players to be incorrectly placed after their provisional games, and created issues that led to very poor matchmaking and inflated LP gains.

After the changes this morning everyone who completed their placements will have to play one more game to be correctly placed.

**So did the fix work?**

Since this morning we've monitored the effects on player MMR and which leagues players were being placed into, and saw that players were looking much closer to their actual ratings. Unfortunately, for players who have climbed ranks rapidly as a result of incorrect placement and inflated LP gains, this correction to their actual rank feels punishing. We know some players were stoked to be climbing higher and faster than they ever have but it’s pretty likely that the matchmaking for those players was a bit of a clown fiesta in the first place, and that their placements and LP gains were largely inflated.

Ultimately, for ranked to be as competitive as possible, we wanted to make sure they (and their opponents) had a fair climb up the ladder and this means resetting everyone to their correct rank. Although for some players, this also means being placed higher after today as their incorrect MMR had identified them as lower than their true rank.

replies.body:
I finished the season at Silver 5 and after playing my 10 flex placements either 6-4 or 7-3 I was placed in bronze 1 which felt fair as my mmr was going down the hole with how I was playing losing many games dropping from silver 2 to silver. However I managed to rank up back to silver 5 didn't lose many games in the progress. With today's change I am dropped to bronze 3.

I do not want to unfairly have to climb once more, my mmr is not be represented

Hi dude, looked into your situation last season and your rank was being held at Silver V rather than demoting into Bronze. It takes being basically a full tier of MMR below your current tier (Silver V) to finally demote out of that tier. So being placed in Bronze this preseason is understandable as placements aren't protected by that same function.

Thats interesting but it doesn't really have anything to do with what he is saying.

He is saying: 
"It was fair that my placements dropped me back into bronze, and its fair that I actually worked my way back up to silver again. But what isn't fair is that I get taken from silver 5 AGAIN (twice in the preseason), and dropped into bronze 3 after one game."

If he ended at silver 5, dropped into bronze 1 through placements, and then worked back into silver 5, i think its pretty safe to say that he is indeed playing at a silver 5 level. Not a bronze 3 level.

Regrettably, the effect of the MMR reset being completely wrong means matchmaking was also wildly inaccurate. Therefore any climbing or dropping done since before yesterday morning cannot be taken into account when determining rank.

Thats a fair point, but this is my rebuttal:

I am currently silver, But if I accidentally got placed in gold V, and (hypothetically) worked my way up to platinum 3, then it could be safe to assume that I can play at a platinum MMR, and would be counter-productive for myself as well as other people, for me to then  be placed in bronze. 

You say that any climbing can not be taken into account when determining rank. 
But pretend that he spent half a year climbing (but was placed in the wrong division initially, and so had to be MMR reset, once RIOT found out)
Would you then ignore that half a year of climbing? 
Even though he was placed wrongly initially, he has proven that the placement was actually correct, (because if he was placed too high, he would have fallen down divisions, and not climbed.)

If it went for half a year unnoticed while matchmaking was completely screwed then we may have provided a different solution, but I still think an mmr reset of some sort would take place. Since this was only a few days, a re-do from the beginning of last season's mmr + proper reset is more reasonable.

Thing is, you're only going to see complaints here from players that placed lower after getting their mmr reset due to the messed up matchmaking. What about all the players who dropped massively in rank due to the joke of an mmr reset and craptastic matchmaking that followed?
This is why we have to apply the same solution to all players, otherwise we risk inflating populations at the top of the ladder with players who got there while matchmaking was so bad.

I suppose the logical solution would be to have no reset at all.
People start the new season at the same place as the last one. 

Its very rare that you hear someone being placed higher than they used to be through placements alone, so this would be beneficial for everyone.

Or maybe a reset, but a softer one. 
e.g. you cant drop below division 5 of the tier you are in, but also cant rise more than 4 divisions above you.

But removing someones year long work by dropping a whole tier (silver 3 to bronze 3), seems a little harsh. People worked for that score, and they haven't done anything to lose it.

I know what you'll say: "But the landscape of the game has changed now that the preseason changes are active, so it is inaccurate to keep the same score now the game is different."

and thats fair enough, but i seriously doubt that people who were platinum, will now be playing a low-gold/high-silver level, just because theres a couple of plants that go boom when you auto attack them.

I know that riot's focus is on the mid-high level of play, and not on the extremely high or the low levels of play.

But while MMR resets don't mean much to diamond/platinum players, for the majority of bronze/silver players trying to get to gold, MMR resets are lethal. Many bronze players spend a whole year slogging to get out of bronze, finally get to silver 3/4 then get reset and begin the climb all the way from bronze 5 again, just to get silver 3/2, then get reset again and start from bronze 4, and climb to silver 1, then get reset again, and have to begin the tedious process all over again. 

When you're platinum, its fine, you drop to low gold, and think 
"Ok well time to get back up again, even if i don't make it, i still get my victorious skin."
but when you're silver and almost gold, and have to start again right from the very bottom every season.
Its soul crushing.

Soul crushing indeed I finally climbed to silver 4 last season then Im straight back to B3 after placements that is where i started last season! 
I know climbing out of bronze isn't hard but its frustrating and it doesn't help me improve i had a consistent 70% win rate last season from b3 all the way to silver 3 why do i have to do it again if i can win so consistently should i really be at that rank?

And those players who rose by sheer luck that matchmaking didn't screw them will naturally fall to where they belong. And if we're taking a utilitarian approach here, are we  just assuming that enough players benefited from bad matchmaking unfairly to justify sending the vast majority of the player base into elo hell? I was consistently silver 1/Gold 5 last season, and the season before that. Then I play one game and now I'm Bronze 3. That's nearly 2 full divisions of loss, you suggesting I've been carried literally every game of the last two seasons and that's the reason I wasn't in Bronze to begin with?

I'm in a similar boat.

I think the data science and matchmaking design team at Riot are not on the same page.
There appears to be bias on certain play styles and behaviours, strongly favouring carry-like-positions and individual actions.  Teamwork, and supports in lower ranks are not rewarded to the same degree.  With a bit more data I could model this to prove my point.

Your friend could have stayed in Gold V last season while their MMR was much lower because it takes a lot of losses to be demoted out of a tier's 5th division.
Given MMR was bugged for Ranked Flex, their placement into Gold 1 was largely incorrect. Since then as we've done the MMR reset over again (correctly this time) your friend's MMR and rank has been correctly calculated.

Your placement into Bronze from Silver 5 seems more likely to be correct as your MMR could have been low but not low enough to demote out of Silver during the 2016 season. It seems likely that you'd get a similar rank after doing your 1 placement game to place again since the fix this morning.

The way it was working was destroying competitive integrity, which defeats the purpose of ranks, hence the need for the fix.

I finished season 6 at Silver 5 35lp. I go to ever website to check my mmr, and all say I am above silver 5 level. Now I know these website are just predictions but it still has to calculate it from somewhere. I was placed in bronze 3 before flex reset (which I was annoyed but dealt with), I climbed all the way back to silver 5, while having to deal with the trolls, afk's and feeders. 

**It was not fun. **

Now after the flex reset I got put back to bronze 3, and your asking me to deal with them all again? It's stuff like this which will lose players from the player base.

Remember that sites like op.gg use their own calculations for mmr, not Riot's, so they will always be inaccurate, and in some cases wildly so. The initial matchmaking was completely broken, and very few people got placed where they should have, you appear to be one of those few. However, even though you spent time and effort on climbing to Silver 5, you did so while the matchmaking was still broken and inaccurate, so those games cannot accurately reflect you skill, hence the reset.

It sucks, but this was the least painful way of fixing a colossal problem.

I've already climbed 2 divisions from silver 4, was 99lp in my placements to silver 1, win a game, back down to silver 4 again. So I was placed correctly the first time? Then why punish me for it?

I was gold 5 last season and was consistently being placed against plats/diamonds in the games I played in flex queue. I feel like I earned that climb, seeing as I was playing with people of a much higher skill cap. It wasn't due to 'inflated mmr', I was earning no more per win than I was at the start of last season. 

It really makes me feel like I wasted a lot of time. I understand that you're 'fixing' an issue, but is it really a 'fix' if it ends up punishing your customers for putting time into climbing? I want to know if you're going to compensate players in some way for this, seeing as a lot of people must have wasted their time trying to climb just to have it reset?

So your initial placement was luckily rather close to your correct placement, but your LP gains afterwards were in fact inflated.

Matchmaking being as bugged as it was, your games saw your team just as often having higher ranked players than the enemy and you retained only a ~50% win rate but still had LP gains between 20 - 30 and losses of less than 15. It might be normal to see large gains initially after placements if you keep a high win rate, but not after so many games while maintaining only an average win rate.

In any case, your expectation was that you were gaining in rank and now that's gone. I know it sucks, but we've had to perform this reset for everyone in order to keep the ladder competitive and get players on equal footing again given how bugged it was.
In retrospect we may have needed to disable ranked until this was sorted, but neither the problem nor the required fix were clear yet and it would have left us with only Blind Pick.

Yeah, fair enough - what's done is done now and there's no changing it I guess, if I'd known I would not have spent so much time playing is all. Even keeping an even win rate is most of the time enough to climb you up in silver though, anyway. 

Really enjoying the changes you've made in the game in general btw, keep up the good works.

A friend and I were fighting plats and diamonds all through our placement games (and even after the placement games) and I was placed S3, which was an improvement from last season from which I was placed s5 after climbing from b4. I was quite happy with these results as so much hard work was put those placements. Now, after doing the one flex game I was placed B4. I would of much rather of redone my placements than be placed off one game, it's extremely unfair to judge a player off one game. Rito, you attempted to fix an issue and I respect that but a lot of people are extremely dissatisfied and the ranks that they have earned are not accurate to their skill, please fix this.

It's not quite so simple, you shouldn't have been vsing plats and diamonds to begin with, that was a major part of the problem. The matchmaking was messed up so bad as to make any games played in flex queue before the fix irrelevant.

Ignoring those games, you ended season 6 in S5 0LP as you mentioned. being in div 5 with 0LP is often indicative of an mmr lower than the reflected rank, since you haven't played enough games in that rank for your mmr to reflect it, and with the soft reset that usually occurs with placements, you will almost always get placed at least a little lower than your end of season rank. B4 is a significant jump from S5, but not unreasonable in your case.

It sucks, but that S3 placement was inaccurate, as was the vast majority of other peoples initial flex placements, hence the need for the fix.

17 wins 8 loses Gold 3

18 wins 8 loses Silver 5

done

You finished season 6 in G5 with 0lp, so S5 is not an unreasonable placement from there. You will almost always be ranked lower after placements, and basically never higher. G3 was an incorrect placement to begin with, and the system was unfair for everyone involved, hence the need for a fix.
